00059 using std::cerr;

00061 
00070 Float32::Float32(const string &n) 
00071     : BaseType(n, dods_float32_c, (xdrproc_t)XDR_FLOAT32)
00072 {
00073 }
00074 
00075 Float32::Float32(const Float32 &copy_from) : BaseType(copy_from)
00076 {
00077     _buf = copy_from._buf;
00078 }
00079     
00080 BaseType *
00081 Float32::ptr_duplicate()
00082 {
00083     return new Float32(*this);
00084 }
00085 
00086 Float32 &
00087 Float32::operator=(const Float32 &rhs)
00088 {
00089     if (this == &rhs)
00090     return *this;
00091 
00092     dynamic_cast<BaseType &>(*this) = rhs;
00093 
00094     _buf = rhs._buf;
00095 
00096     return *this;
00097 }
00098 
00099 unsigned int
00100 Float32::width()
00101 {
00102     return sizeof(dods_float32);
00103 }
00104 
00105 bool
00106 Float32::serialize(const string &dataset, DDS &dds, XDR *sink, 
00107            bool ce_eval)
00108 {
00109     dds.timeout_on();
00110 
00111     if (!read_p())
00112     read(dataset);      // read() throws Error and InternalErr
00113 
00114     if (ce_eval && !dds.eval_selection(dataset))
00115     return true;
00116 
00117     dds.timeout_off();
00118 
00119     if (!xdr_float(sink, &_buf))
00120     throw Error(
00121 "Network I/O Error. Could not send float 32 data.\n\
00122 This may be due to a bug in DODS, on the server or a\n\
00123 problem with the network connection.");
00124 
00125     return true;
00126 }
00127 
00128 bool
00129 Float32::deserialize(XDR *source, DDS *, bool)
00130 {
00131     if (!xdr_float(source, &_buf))
00132     throw Error(
00133 "Network I/O Error. Could not read float 32 data. This may be due to a\n\
00134 bug in DODS or a problem with the network connection.");
00135 
00136     return false;
00137 }
00138 
00139 unsigned int
00140 Float32::val2buf(void *val, bool)
00141 {
00142     // Jose Garcia
00143     // This method is public therefore and I believe it has being designed
00144     // to be use by read which must be implemented on the surrogated library,
00145     // thus if the pointer val is NULL, is an Internal Error. 
00146     if(!val)
00147     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__,
00148               "The incoming pointer does not contain any data.");
00149 
00150     _buf = *(dods_float32 *)val;
00151 
00152     return width();
00153 }
00154 
00155 unsigned int
00156 Float32::buf2val(void **val)
00157 {
00158     // Jose Garcia
00159     // The same comment justifying throwing an Error in val2buf applies here.
00160     if (!val)
00161     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "NULL pointer.");
00162 
00163     if (!*val)
00164     *val = new dods_float32;
00165 
00166     *(dods_float32 *)*val =_buf;
00167 
00168     return width();
00169 }
00170 
00176 dods_float32 
00177 Float32::value()
00178 {
00179     return _buf;
00180 }
00181 
00182 void 
00183 Float32::print_val(ostream &os, string space, bool print_decl_p)
00184 {
00185     os.precision(DODS_FLT_DIG);
00186 
00187     if (print_decl_p) {
00188     print_decl(os, space, false);
00189     os << " = " << _buf << ";" << endl;
00190     }
00191     else 
00192     os << _buf;
00193 }
00194 
00195 void 
00196 Float32::print_val(FILE *out, string space, bool print_decl_p)
00197 {
00198     // FIX: need to set precision in the printing somehow.
00199     // os.precision(DODS_FLT_DIG);
00200 
00201     if (print_decl_p) {
00202     print_decl(out, space, false);
00203     fprintf( out, " = %.6g;\n", _buf ) ;
00204     }
00205     else 
00206     fprintf( out, "%.6g", _buf ) ;
00207 }
00208 
00209 bool
00210 Float32::ops(BaseType *b, int op, const string &dataset)
00211 {
00212     // Extract the Byte arg's value.
00213     if (!read_p() && !read(dataset)) {
00214       // Jose Garcia
00215       // Since the read method is virtual and implemented outside
00216       // libdap++ if we can not read the data that is the problem 
00217       // of the user or of whoever wrote the surrogate library
00218       // implemeting read therefore it is an internal error.
00219       throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "This value not read!");
00220     }
00221 
00222     // Extract the second arg's value.
00223     if (!b->read_p() && !b->read(dataset)) {
00224       // Jose Garcia
00225       // Since the read method is virtual and implemented outside
00226       // libdap++ if we can not read the data that is the problem 
00227       // of the user or of whoever wrote the surrogate library
00228       // implemeting read therefore it is an internal error.
00229       throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "This value not read!");
00230     }
00231 
00232     switch (b->type()) {
00233       case dods_byte_c:
00234     return rops<dods_float32, dods_byte, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_byte> >
00235         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Byte *>(b)->_buf, op);
00236       case dods_int16_c:
00237     return rops<dods_float32, dods_int16, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_int16> >
00238         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Int16 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00239       case dods_uint16_c:
00240     return rops<dods_float32, dods_uint16, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_uint16> >
00241         (_buf, dynamic_cast<UInt16 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00242       case dods_int32_c:
00243     return rops<dods_float32, dods_int32, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_int32> >
00244         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Int32 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00245       case dods_uint32_c:
00246     return rops<dods_float32, dods_uint32, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_uint32> >
00247         (_buf, dynamic_cast<UInt32 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00248       case dods_float32_c:
00249     return rops<dods_float32, dods_float32, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_float32> >
00250         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Float32 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00251       case dods_float64_c:
00252     return rops<dods_float32, dods_float64, Cmp<dods_float32, dods_float64> >
00253         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Float64 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00254       default:
00255     return false;
00256     }
00257 }

00272 // DODSFilter::send_data(). The old DDS::send() is still there but is
00273 // depracated.
00274 // Added 'smart timeouts' to all the variable classes. This means that
00275 // the new server timeouts are active only for the data read and CE
00276 // evaluation. This went inthe BaseType::serialize() methods because it
00277 // needed to time both the read() calls and the dds::eval() calls.

00321 // Revision 1.16.4.4  2001/10/02 17:01:52  jimg
00322 // Made the behavior of serialize and deserialize uniform. Both methods now
00323 // use Error exceptions to signal problems with network I/O and InternalErr
00324 // exceptions to signal other problems. The return codes, always true for
00325 // serialize and always false for deserialize, are now meaningless. However,
00326 // by always returning a code that means OK, old code should continue to work.
00327 //
00328 // Revision 1.18  2001/09/28 17:50:07  jimg
00329 // Merged with 3.2.7.
00330 //
00331 // Revision 1.16.4.3  2001/09/07 00:38:35  jimg
00332 // Sequence::deserialize(...) now reads all the sequence values at once.
00333 // Its call semantics are the same as the other classes' versions. Values
00334 // are stored in the Sequence object using a vector<BaseType *> for each
00335 // row (those are themselves held in a vector). Three new accessor methods
00336 // have been added to Sequence (row_value() and two versions of var_value()).
00337 // BaseType::deserialize(...) now always returns true. This matches with the
00338 // expectations of most client code (the seqeunce version returned false
00339 // when it was done reading, but all the calls for sequences must be changed
00340 // anyway). If an XDR error is found, deserialize throws InternalErr.
00341 //
00342 // Revision 1.17  2001/08/24 17:46:22  jimg
00343 // Resolved conflicts from the merge of release 3.2.6
00344 //
00345 // Revision 1.16.4.2  2001/08/18 00:17:39  jimg
00346 // Removed WIN32 compile guards from using statements.
00347 //
00348 // Revision 1.16.4.1  2001/07/28 01:10:42  jimg
00349 // Some of the numeric type classes did not have copy ctors or operator=.
00350 // I added those where they were needed.
00351 // In every place where delete (or delete []) was called, I set the pointer
00352 // just deleted to zero. Thus if for some reason delete is called again
00353 // before new memory is allocated there won't be a mysterious crash. This is
00354 // just good form when using delete.
00355 // I added calls to www2id and id2www where appropriate. The DAP now handles
00356 // making sure that names are escaped and unescaped as needed. Connect is
00357 // set to handle CEs that contain names as they are in the dataset (see the
00358 // comments/Log there). Servers should not handle escaping or unescaping
00359 // characters on their own.
00360 //
00361 // Revision 1.16  2000/10/06 01:26:04  jimg
00362 // Changed the way serialize() calls read(). The status from read() is
00363 // returned by the Structure and Sequence serialize() methods; ignored by
00364 // all others. Any exceptions thrown by read() are caught and discarded.
00365 // serialize() returns false if read() throws an exception. This should
00366 // be fixed once all the servers build using the new read() definition.
00367 //
00368 // Revision 1.15  2000/09/22 02:17:20  jimg

00371 // wrapped headers included in other headers in those guard symbols (to cut
00372 // down on extraneous file processing - See Lakos).
00373 //
00374 // Revision 1.14  2000/09/21 16:22:07  jimg
00375 // Merged changes from Jose Garcia that add exceptions to the software.
00376 // Many methods that returned error codes now throw exectptions. There are
00377 // two classes which are thrown by the software, Error and InternalErr.
00378 // InternalErr is used to report errors within the library or errors using
00379 // the library. Error is used to reprot all other errors. Since InternalErr
00380 // is a subclass of Error, programs need only to catch Error.
00381 //
